text: What went we out into this wilderness to find? Leaving our country, kindred, our father’s houses? We have travailed a vast ocean... For what? For what?
(overlapping) We must ask thee to be silent! CLOSE ON: CALEB (11), THOMASIN’S brother. He doesn’t blin just listens. Fear in his belly.
(overlapping) (overlapping) Was it not for the pure and No More! faithful dispensation of the Gospels and the Kingdom of God?

We are your judges, and not you ours! MEDIUM WIDE: THOMASIN & CALEB stand in a row beside the TWINS, JONAS & MERCY (5) and their PREGNANT MOTHER, KATHERINE, WHOSE FACE WE DO NOT SEE. JUST THE CHILDREN.
I cannot be judged by false contented Christians under an un- separated church! An English king’s church.

BLACK CLOTHED DIGNITARIES sitting at a long table on a ra platform in front of the pulpit. Their dour faces are exasperated. WILLIAM, back to camera, stands below them in the center the primitive church. His family by his side. The whole congregation of about fifty men, women and chil are all crammed together, all standing in heavy silence. on one side, women on the other. Their eyes on WILLIAM.
Must you continue to dishonor the laws of the commonwealth and the church with your prideful conceit?
If my conscience sees it fit.
Then shall you be banished out of this plantation’s liberties!
I would be glad on it. Pause.
Then take your leave, and trouble us no further. CLOSE ON: WILLIAM’s eyes burn indignantly below his furro brow.
How sadly hath The Lord testified against you. He turns to walk out of the meeting house.
Katherine. MED: THE CHILDREN, scared and confused, are yanked throug THE THRONG OF ANGRY PURITANS by their FATHER AND MOTHER. THOMASIN stays still. Shocked.
Come along now. Come along.  THOMASIN doesn’t move. She doesn’t want to leave. Her brother grabs her in the commotion.
Thomasin! Come.

The view of the pitiful, snow-covered MEDIEVAL-LOOKING VILLAGE disappears as TWO MILITIA MEN slowly close the plantation’s tall PALISADE DOORS. A FEW NAUMKEAG TRADERS with painted faces and A ROUGH LOOKING WHITE MAN stand ne by with their goods. THOMASIN, CALEB, THE TWINS, and FOWLER THE DOG, watch the doors close as they rock back and forth sitting in a rick two-wheeled CART. WILLIAM walks alongside the workhorse pulling a cart stra with a trunk, a chair, clinking pots and pans and few oth miscellaneous articles. Surely not enough to survive on. KATHERINE, sits in the cart with the children. She sings:
(sings) I will confess Jehovah with all heart in secret and in assembly of the just. THOMASIN rests her head on KATHERINE’S PREGNANT BELLY. KATHERINE strokes THOMASIN’S hair. THOMASIN LOOKS BACK TO
THOMASIN joins her hymn:
(sings) Great are the works of our Lord, sought out of all that in them do delight. EVERYONE joins:

(sings) Beautiful and glorious his work is, and his righteousness endureth forever... All but WILLIAM keep their eyes on the safe PLANTATION W as they head into a VAST UNTOUCHED WILDERNESS. Their song hope slowly fading away. Hold.
THE FAMILY as they travel slowly in the light March snow. Nature envelopes them. They walk on. And on. Hold. BLACK.

text: He sits up, the warm afternoon light hitting his hopeful, teary cheeks. He lifts his hands toward heaven. The wind blows. KATHERINE takes his hand. THE FAMILY is in a circle, on their knees, in joyful, silent prayer. Their faces beamin Before them is a BEAUTIFUL, IDYLLIC NATURAL CLEARING OF ROLLING HILLS... but... the clearing is surrounded by a FOREST - A DARK AN

THE PRESENCE OF THE WOOD IS PROFOUND, DISTURBING, OMINOUS

text: But the family is wrapped in prayer. BLACK. HOLD. AUDIO: The wind blows.  EXT. THE SAME CLEARING —- DAWN - NOVEMBER It is now late autumn. Anorexic CORNSTALKS are scattered across a muddy field. A FLEDGLING FARM sits on top of a hill at the foot of THE WOOD. MONSTROUS TREES loom over THE RAMSHACKLE COTTAGE. I crooked clapboards to are beginning to grey and the gable thatch to brown. Behind the house are a few shoddy struct and scrap-wood fences for keeping in the small amount of livestock. The frame of the INCOMPLETE BARN looks as if i will collapse at any moment. Tools and raw lumber littler the yard.
CLOSE ON: THOMASIN. Her large blue eyes gaze earnestly toward heaven. Her chin rests on little dirty fingers. Sh says her words with surprising acceptance:

O most merciful father: I here confess I have lived in sin. I have been idle of my work, disobedient of mine parents, neglectful of my prayer. I have, in secret, played upon thy sabbath and broken every one of thy commandments in thought... followed the desires of my own will, and not the holy Spirit. I know I deserve all shame and misery in this life, and everlasting hell-fire. But I beg thee, for the sake of thy Son. Forgive me. Show me mercy. Show me thy light. I thank thee that thou hast defended me this night, and brought me safe unto this day. These and all other graces, I beg at thy hands in that prayer which Christ himself hath taught me:
MED CLOSE: KATHERINE BREAST FEEDS SAMUEL, THE BABY, now 6 months old.
Our Father which art in heaven, hallowed be thy Name. Thy kingdom come.

WIDE: WILLIAM AND CALEB have their backs to camera workin a patchy, dying cornfield. Their clothes now well worn. WILLIAM cuts the corn from the stalks. CALEB bundles the chaff into shocks. JONAS AND MERCY fill baskets of with t ears of corn. It is hard repetitive work for all. But the are used to it.
Thy will be done even in earth, as it is in heaven. Give us this day our daily bread.
MED WIDE: THOMASIN shovels dung out of the shed. It is heavy. But she is used to it.
And forgive us our debts, as we also forgive our debtors.

MED TRACKING: KATHERINE hands THE BABY to THOMASIN. KATHERINE needs both of her hands to stoke the fire of th outdoor bake-oven. THOMASIN walks away with SAM THE BABY, disappearing into the cloud of grey smoke.
And lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from evil: for thine is the kingdom, and the power, and the glory for ever. Amen. BLACK. AUDIO: THE BABY’S LAUGHTER is heard. Then, THOMASIN’S pla
Where’s Sam? Where is Sam? (MORE)
(Pause). Peeeeeeep...
Boo! CLOSE ON: SAMUEL, THE BABY, is lying in the grass. He is stunned, smiling with huge baby eyes and a little w mouth. HE SQUEALS WITH LAUGHTER! Too adorable!
There you are! There you are! SAMUEL laughs more and more. He is clearly being tickled!
SAMUEL'S laughter subsides. He breathes heavily, almost panting. He lets out a quiet half-laugh. He sounds worried.
Peeeeeep...
Boo! CLOSE ON: SAMUEL. He shrieks with laughter again! He rais his arms up and down in delight and kicks his legs.
(whispered) Where is Sam? Where’s Sam? Where is that little man? (pause). (MORE )
Peeeeeeep...
LOW CLOSE ON: THOMASIN, kneeling on the ground. She uncov her big sparkling eyes in the “peek-a-boo” fashion and shouts:
Boo! Her rosy-cheeked face is frozen in joy. Suddenly, her eyes register what is in front of her... Her compelling smile disappears... Her face loses all color...
Sam?

CLOSE ON: Nothing. The dead grass where SAMUEL had been lying. All is silent except for THOMASIN’S panicking breath. Whe is he? The wind blows. THE CAMERA slowly tilts up through the tall grass and wee toward... «+. THE WOOD. The wild grass that leads to the edge of THE WOOD is MOVI SLIGHTLY, as if something had just run through it. THOMASIN screams:
Sam! Samuel!! THOMASIN runs into frame and stops, STARING INTO THE OPEN OF THE PRIMEVAL FOREST. IT SEEMS TO BECKON HER.

The autumn mist is thick. Boney-fingered branches crack i  the wind. A SMALL HUNCHED FIGURE in a tattered RED CLOAK hobbles quickly through the enormous mossy trees. A distorted old breath comes from under THE RED HOOD, wheezing, trying to keep pace. From a little lower in the cloak comes the sound of a gargling BABY. One of SAMUEL'S HANDS pokes out. Dusk is at its end. INT. THE WITCH’S HOVEL - NIGHT DARKNESS. It is almost impossible to see. Passing through the shadows, extremely old and bent HANDS with long dirty talons briefly catch the firelight. They place SAMUEL upon the center of a crude table. Overwhelme the dark, he senses the danger. His delicate baby FINGERS open and close reflexively, grasping at the air. Seen in flickering glimpses, the greasy RED CLOAK falls t the dirt floor. TINY FEET step around THE CLOAK and kick square-toed shoes. Jagged, fungal toe-nails poke out of soiled wool stockings. THE OLD HANDS grab the BABY’S COLLAR, tear open his linen shift, and strip it off the child. SAMUEL starts to cry. THE FIGURE steps away from the table, her back to camera. Hobbling in and out of blackness of the hovel, she takes her bonnet and scanty grey locks fall to her shoulders, snaking across her bent spine. She removes the rest of he filthy clothes, and for an instant, HER NAKED BODY is revealed... before she moves back into shadow. HER HANDS reach up to the low THATCH CEILING, over THE BA and tear out a mossy clump. Little bits of dirt and reed, other natural scantlings fall on SAMUEL. BRIGHT MOONLIGHT shines through the hole, bathing the child in its light. OFF SCREEN, THE OLD WOMAN hums a haunting song. Her HANDS stroke the baby tenderly and pinches the fatty areas arou his thighs and biceps. Her HAND take a LARGE RUSTY KNIFE... she holds it up over child's breast... she continues to hum her song... CAMERA ON: The humpback and scabby head of THE OLD WOMAN. She brings the knife up... and then down in a swift motio (WE DO NOT SEE THE BABY, only the back of THE OLD WOMAN)  10. AUDIO: CHOP! THE BABY WAILS.

Back to camera, THE OLD WOMAN'S SILHOUETTE sits by a low- burning fire. She grinds at her MORTAR AND PESTLE. One can easily assum its contents. Scattered beside her are a messy assortment of EARTHEN JA Each jar emits a more awful stench than the other.
Illuminated in the dimmest traces of moonlight, THE OLD W has A THICK BLOODY GREASE in her hands. She rubs this UNG all over her NAKED BODY.
She rubs THE UNGUENT on THE WOODEN HANDLE OF A BROOMSITCK foams around her thumb and forefinger.

CAMERA ON HER BACK: Barely visible, THE NAKED OLD WOMAN stands near the hearth. She mounts THE BROOM. She is still. Suddenly, her head moves. First a jerk, then it slows. He gaze going upward. Her eyes roll to the back of her head and her eyelids flu in and out of the moonlight. Her face remains unseen. SHE TREMBLES AND COLLAPSES TO THE GROUND.

head_text.subj: SHE BREATHES HEAVILY AND RHYTHMICALLY, GROANING AND GROAN
TREMORING IN THE DIRT AND DARKNESS.

-— THROUGH THE THATCH SMOKE-HOLE OF HER ROOF, ASCENDING I  11. THE NIGHT TOWARD THE MOON. Her naked body scrapes against the branches, clicking, clacking and cracking as she rises. “Clickety-clackety, clickety-clackety, clickety-clackety.” BLACK. HOLD. AUDIO: A rooster crows. Other quite farm noises.

A WOODEN SHUTTER is unlatched from a small glass-less win A WOMAN'S MUFFLED CRYING AND MUMBLING IS HEARD. Dim dawn light hits CALEB’S gaunt, freckled face. His lig eyes are full of worries. Painfully anxious. The dawn glows red. CALEB picks up his homespun doublet. He stumbles quietly and through the pile of sleeping SWEATY-FACED SIBLINGS an straw mattresses on the floor. Dwindling food stores hang from the pitched ceiling, almost knocking his head. MERCY is curled up with JONAS, who sucks his thumb. THOMASIN has JONAS’ DIRTY FEET near her FACE. As CALEB takes a big step, THOMASIN moves in her sleep. CALEB looks down and notices THE SIDE OF HIS SISTER’S BRE in her somewhat open shift, and her faint armpit hair. Pause. Embarrassed, CALEB looks away. THOMASIN moves again. Blankets rustle. CALEB look back: THOMASIN’S face is contorted in pain. Her eyes twitch und her eyelids. SHE IS HAVING A NIGHTMARE. CALEB hesitates. He kneels down and gently shakes her shoulders:
(whispers, almost inaudible) Thomasin.  12. CALEB shakes her again...

(whispered) Thomasin. THOMASIN’S EYES OPEN and she gasps clenching her fists. CALEB puts his hand gently over her mouth. She jerks, disoriented. CALEB pantomimes a “shh” with his other hand. They pause. THEY LISTEN TO THEIR MOTHER'S WEEPING AND PRAYING from downstairs... CALEB uncovers THOMASIN’S mouth. She looks at him. Pause. THOMASIN’S face is as mournful as their mother’s weeping. eyes beg for comfort.
(whispers, almost inaudible) Sleep. All will be well. Sleep. CALEB keeps his eyes on his sister till she reluctantly l back in bed. Then, he climbs down the rickety ladder to...

«+. the ground floor of the family’s extremely primitive room home. The stench of squalor and smoke hangs in the a FOWLER THE DOG, is near an EMPTY WOODEN CRADLE. He is up CALEB steps over his parent’s chamber pot, and pushes a wandering HEN away from his shoes that are near his paren bedside. He can still hear his MOTHER crying softly from behind th shabby bed curtains. THE DOG whines and tries to peek in. CALEB turns his head to the door and puts on his doublet. THE FRONT DOOR is half open...  13.
CALEB walks out the door... past a TALL PILE OF STACKED FIREWOOD... past the chopping block and AXE...

-.. He continues toward THE SILHOUETTED FIGURE at the bot of the hill in the CORNFIELD. It’s WILLIAM. CALEB approaches tentatively. He gently touches WILLIAM'S shoulder... He is startled and turns: He sees his son out of the corner of his eye, peeking thr his long thinning hair. HE TURNS AWAY. His smoky voice rumbles:
Caleb. CALEB tries to initiate contact.

God give you good morrow. (Pause. ) WILLIAM frowns, biting on a his mustache and beard. His coarse hand holds an EAR OF INDIAN CORN. His wide-bri hat is in the other. THE CORN IS SHRIVELED, HALF GROWN AN ROTTING. A DISGUSTING MALIGNANT FUNGUS is bursting betwee its kernels. CHICKENS cluck several yards away.
All are still a-bed. (Pause. ) Save Mother.
No ease to rise on a grey day. The Devil holds fast your eyelids.
I‘’ll wake ‘em.  14.
Let ‘em be. CALEB looks surprised.
Thy mother’s not slept a night since. WILLIAM looks at the ground.
We can search no longer, Caleb. We cannot. If not a wolf, hunger’d have taken him yet. Pause. WILLIAM looks at the devastated cornfield. Disfigured cor of infected corn-ears lay upon the grey soil.

head_text.subj: WILLIAM THROWS THE EAR OF CORN HE HAS BEEN HOLDING WITH A

text: HIS MIGHT. It disappears into the hazy dawn.
Let’s to The Wood. CALEB looks very surprised.
I've been a-laying traps for some while - before even this new misery.
Within The Wood?
Will you not help thy father?
You and mother have always forbad us to set foot there.
This is our home now. Fear it not. Eh? Did not we build our house of timbers? (Pause. ) We must conquer this wood. It will not consume us. Pause.  15.
Perchance you snared that wolf.
Aye. Fetch thy hat, tis bitter cold. WILLIAM smiles hopefully at CALEB again and touches his b head. CALEB smiles back and runs toward the house.
And the gun.

WILLIAM is only a small speck beneath the THREATENING TRE The thick trunks moan and creak, swaying ever so slightly the wind. He walks quietly into the darkness of THE WOOD. CALEB stands still, several paces back with FOWLER THE DO HE HOLDS HIS FATHER’S MUSKET. CALEB looks up at the high treetops, afraid to enter. FOWLER whimpers a little. WILLIAM calls from within:
Caleb! Caleb catches up and crosses THE FORBIDDEN THRESHOLD.

Father and son walk in the early morning mist, FOWLER by their side. Their wooden powder flasks clink and clatter against thei bony chests. Grey leaves crunch beneath their feet. A dense pine canopy bristles above them, shadowing the fo floor. CALEB’S LESSON echoes through the trees:  16.
Art thou then born holy and righteous?
No, nay! My first father sinned and I in him. CALEB wants to be serious, however, with all the danger a excitement a small but uncontrollable grin has appeared o his face. He recites with pride:
Art thou then born a sinner?
Aye. I was conceived in sin, and born in - iniquity.
Good. Then what is thy birth sin?
Adam's sin imputed to me, and a corrupt nature dwelling within me.
Well-remembered Caleb. Very well. And canst thou tell me what thy corrupt nature is?
My corrupt nature is empty of grace, bent unto sin, only unto sin, and that continually. CALEB pauses for a moment. THE WORDS OF HIS CATECHISM SIN IN.

Soft now. They come upon a LARGE OVERTURNED TREE. Its sprawling roo system is far taller than WILLIAM. CALEB watches WILLIAM find a TRAP he had laid near it. WILLIAM kicks THE TRAP softly with the toe of his boot. IT IS SHUT. THERE IS NO CATCH. WILLIAM hides his disappointment.  17.

We must lay’t again. CALEB goes to the trap. He stops himself from touching th big iron teeth. He looks imploringly at his father. May I it? WILLIAM nods and smiles affirmatively. CALEB bends down to open the jaws. He struggles a bit.
Now, mind thy hand Caleb. Mind thy hand. CALEB slows his work... thinking again:
Was... was Samuel born a sinner? WILLIAM pauses. He nods “yes.” CALEB was expecting that answer.
How might then -
(overlapping) We pray he hath entered God’s Kingdom. Pause.
What wickedness hath he done?
Place faith in God - Caleb, mind thy hand, I say. (Pause. ) We'll speak no more on thy brother.
Why?
He hath disappeared not one week past, yet you and Mother utter not his name.
Caleb, look to thy work or I’1l lay it myself.
Tell me.
Tell thee what? He is gone, Caleb.
(overlapping) Is he in hell?
Caleb!
Mother will not stop her prayer...
Hand me that engine!
An if died? If I died this day?
What is this?
I hold evil in my heart. My sins are not pardoned.
Thou art youngly yet -
(overlapping) An if God will not hear my prayers?
Caleb -
(overlapping) Tell me!

Look you, I love thee marvelous well, but ‘tis God alone, not man, what knows who is a son of Abraham and who is not. Who is good and who is evil. Fain would I tell thee Sam sleeps in Jesus, that thou wilt, that I will, but I cannot tell thee that. None can. 19. CALEB looks down and starts fiddling with the trap again.
But you and Mother... You have made covenant. You have a place in Heaven.
I keep an unfeigned grief for the want of grace. I can do no more. (Long pause). Caleb? CALEB keeps his eyes on the trap.
Where are these from?
Caleb, list me.
I do.
From Indian Thom and Old Slater, when last they passed through. Move it thither.
What did you trade? Very long pause.
Thy mother’s silver cup. It is clear from CALEB’S face that this was not be traded. something to  20.
Let’s recover the rest.

CLOSE ON: THOMASIN staring forward intensely. Curious. Cautious. Behind her, MERCY rides JONAS like a horse. JONAS makes G NOISES. THOMASIN stands in front of her parents’ bed. The curtain are still closed. She walks forward slowly and peeks in through some frayed holes in the curtains: KATHERINE lies on the bed, her hands clenched together, h eyes closed. She whispers an inaudible prayer. A sadder face has never been seen.

CLOSE ON: THOMASIN, still affected by the sight of her mother. She carries a heavy pail of water on her head, bracing it with one hand. She can’t hold it up very well and the gro is muddy and upturned. With every step across the farmyar water sloshes out of the bucket on to her shoulders, soak her. She shudders with frustration. She puts the bucket down for a moment to wipe her cold no She picks it up again and keeps walking. She’s used to it but today it is too much.
THOMASIN shovels dung out of the GOAT-SHED. Nanny goats b and walk by her. In the distance, THE TWINS are heard singing nursery rhym
Jonas, Mercy! Come hither! THOMASIN keeps shoveling. Shoveling.  21.
Jonas! Mercy!! More shoveling... THOMASIN stops. HOLD ON: THOMASIN. Something swells within her. She throws the shovel down i the dungheap and walks away from her work.
THOMASIN kneels at the spot where SAMUEL disappeared. She runs her fingers tenderly through the grass. She looks into THE WOOD. Pause. How could this have happened?
CALEB & WILLIAM come upon another trap. No catch.
Another trap. Nothing. CALEB looks up at his father. WILLIAM turns around quickly before meeting eyes with his son.
They walk on. CALEB is as anxious as WILLIAM is downtrodd FOWLER is not with them. WILLIAM puts his fingers in his mouth and whistles a LOUD WHISTLE.  22.
Fowler! Fowler! (whistles) Fool of an animal.
Fowler! Suddenly, FOWLER barks, running through the trees. WILLIAM and CALEB see him. THEY SEE SOMETHING ELSE RUNNING TOO. FOWLER is tracking something!

Fowler! (whistles) What is’t? FOWLER points. WILLIAM and CALEB look ahead: AN ENORMOUS LONG-LEGGED HARE HOPS OUT INTO THE CLEARING. THE HARE sits very still. ITS FUR IS COARSE AND ODD. WILLIAM gives CALEB a look instructing him to be quiet. WILLIAM barks at FOWLER:
Fowler, bay it! FOWLER runs after THE HARE! He chases it in a wide circle around the clearing. Both running hard as they can. CALEB hands his father the heavy MUSKET.
Praise God. Look at the size. Make haste Caleb. Rushing, WILLIAM spills powder all over the barrel of the gun.
Fie upon’t! He blows at the powder, probably not hard enough. CALEB holds the smoldering length of hemp.  23.
Father, there’s primer upon the -
Peace now, hand me the match. The match cord goes out.
Ah! WILLIAM hold his hand out to CALEB.
The match.
It died.
Light it apace Caleb!
The primer...
Caleb!! CALEB relights the matchcord and puts it in place. FOWLER chases THE HARE back to where it first appeared. THE HARE STOPS RUNNING. It breathes softly. FOWLER is panting.

head_text.subj: THEN, THE HARE TURNS TOWARD WILLIAM AND CALEB... AND STAR

text: FOWLER barks at THE STRANGE HARE. CALEB can’t believe the sight! WILLIAM'S finger shakes.

head_text.subj: IT STARES RIGHT AT WILLIAM AND CALEB AS IF IT WERE ENCHAN

text: FOWLER keeps barking ferociously. CALEB watches intently. THE MATCH CORD is burning steady.  24. WILLIAM pulls the trigger:
THE MUSKET MISFIRES IN WILLIAM’S FACE. THE HARE RUNS AWAY. WILLIAM yelps and puts his hands to his face, falling to ground.
Father! WILLIAM breathes quickly.
Father? WILLIAM turns his face into the ground and clenches his fists. His breath slackens. Silence.
Father?! WILLIAM sits up, but cannot look CALEB in the eye. CALEB puts his hand on his FATHER’S shoulder.
We’ll make a catch father, I know it. WILLIAM gives in and embraces CALEB tightly for a moment. FOWLER wanders over and kisses WILLIAM’S blackened face.
off Fowler. WILLIAM lets go of CALEB and stands, making embarrassed grunting noises to pull himself together.

FATHER AND SON walk completely defeated and empty handed. The wind whistles through the trees. The sun is still not shining.  25. CALEB notices THE VEINS ON WILLIAM'S HAND PULSING. Only the crunching of leaves beneath their feet. Crunch, crunch, crunch. CRUNCH, CRUNCH, CRUNCH. (at the same time)
Caleb... Father- Pause.
Speak none of this to Mother. None. CALEB makes an ambivalent noise that sounds similar to an “Bye.” Long pause.
She -
(overlapping) An if -

An if what? Go to. I’d not suffer thee to lie. Go to. (pause. ) When we have brought her home that damnéd wolf, she will be glad on it and all shall be known. But now ‘twould be a greater burthen on her heart. She is over-wrought already. CALEB nods.
‘Tis heedless to tell of this now. Heedless. (pause. )  26.
Aye.
Let’s not speak on this again. CALEB nods.
Caleb?
Aye, Father. Pause.
Now, canst thou tell your father what is... sin?
Transgression of God’s Law.
Aye. Good. Canst tell me... ah... Canst thou tell me... CALEB looks at his father. WILLIAM'S mouth stays open for long pause. Thinking. His hypocrisy clouds his head.

A huge feral-looking BILLY GOAT, with enormous horns and black hair, bleats and grunts. He bucks wildly, kicking u muck and mud. The young twins, JONAS and MERCY, chase THE GOAT, waving sticks above their heads, laughing and singing:

Black Phillip, Black Phillip A crown grows out his head Black Phillip, Black Phillip To nanny queen is wed Jump to the fence post Running in the stall Black Phillip, Black Phillip King of all. THE HENS are clucking madly, flapping about. THE NANNY GO are crying. BURT, THE WORKHORSE neighs in the small half- built horse barn.  27.
CALEB AND WILLIAM, stumbling over the fence, run into the yard. WILLIAM tries to find a way to cut in and break up the commotion. CALEB flanks him.
Get thee back! Get thee back!
Phillip! Back!
(sing) Black Phillip, Black Phillip, King of sky and land. Black Phillip, Black Phillip King of sea and sand. We are ye servants We are ye men Black Phillip eats the lions From the lions’ den.

How now, you two! Stop this mischief! WILLIAM runs in front of THE BILLY GOAT and CALEB pulls T TWINS aside. Poultry flies wild. THE GOAT runs toward WILLIAM. WILLIAM tries to grab its back legs. He misses, nearly falling down. THE GOAT flies by, chasing the chickens into THE HOUSE KATHERINE runs out of the house, the GOAT heading toward KATHERINE shrieks. She runs to THE CHILDREN. text: Ope’ the gate Caleb, Ope’ the gate!  28. CALEB opens the gate. KATHERINE immediately grabs his arm tearing him out of the way. She holds him and THE TWINS c to her. WILLIAM drives THE GOAT in to his stall by his legs. THE KICKS...

head_text.subj: WILLIAM SLIPS AND FALLS IN A BIG PILE OF DUNG
CALEB AND THE WHOLE FAMILY LOOKS AT HIM.

text: THE BILLY GOAT is calm. He eats some fodder near WILLIAM. Chickens cluck. JONAS and MERCY laugh.
I‘1l have thee quiet. CALEB watches his father get up. WILLIAM looks at his wife. Her eyes are cloudy from lack sleep. She holds CALEB tightly. She’s not laughing.
Whither were you and Caleb this morn? WILLIAM rises to go towards her tenderly. She steps back and turns away from her husband. She calls: KATHERINE (CONT’D) Thomasin! WILLIAM goes toward her again.
Kate...
(overlapping) Thomasin! Thomasin! THOMASIN comes running to the farmyard out of breath. KATHERINE (CONT’D) (To William) How could you disappear! (To Thomasin) (MORE )
KATHERINE (CONT’D) And thee! I told thee to keep watch of Jonas and Mercy.
I was and I bade them help me and they paid me no mind. I was a- getting - Beside her JONAS is pulling on MERCY’S cheek. MERCY tries to laugh.
(overlapping, calmly) Stop that.
(to Thomasin) What’s the matter with thee, Thomasin? What’s the matter with thee? Take thy father’s rags to the brook and wash em.
Tis only dung.
They would pay me no mind -

(overlapping) And brush out his woolens. Help him! THOMASIN is shut down. KATHERINE (CONT’D) (to Caleb) My lamb. KATHERINE kisses CALEB’S head. CALEB WATCHES THOMASIN as she helps her father take off h soiled clothing. THERE IS SOMETHING TOO FAMILIAR IN THE W THOMASIN TOUCHES HER FATHER’S BODY AS SHE UNDRESSES HIM. IS INNOCENT - IT IS SUBTLE - BUT SHE IS TOO OLD FOR IT.

She keeps with the problem at hand:  30. KATHERINE (CONT’D) It gave me such a fright to find thee gone. (to William) I’‘ll not be left here alone. Dost hear? The morning's work is well behindhand. Where were you? Meanwhile, JONAS continues to pull at his sister’s cheek. With every tug MERCY’S eyes widen and he holds back laugh MERCY can’t take it: she lets out a scream, followed by a tearful giggle.
Jonas! Leave thy sister be!
She likes it.
William?
Cannot a father spend Godly time with his son? JONAS gives another tug on MERCY’S cheek and she screams again.
Jonas!
Father said stop it.
Thomasin! MERCY laughs.
She likes it! MERCY keeps laughing.
See.
Stop it!  31.
Stop it each of you! Stop it.
As you like. KATHERINE turns cold and walks toward the house. WILLIAM is stuck. He cannot tell her. CALEB looks at his father’s sad face... SUDDENLY, CALEB calls out to his mother:
We went to find apples! (Pause. ) WILLIAM'S face goes white.
In the valley. I had thought I had seen an apple tree in the valley. Father brought the gun, for if we glanced that wolf again-
(overlapping) Why did you not tell me?

Father wanted it a surprise to cheer you, and so... but, there were none. I thought I had seen them. KATHERINE looks at CALEB and WILLIAM. She clearly doubts story. Pause. CALEB looks imploringly at her. She smiles hesitantly, and she concedes... barely.
I like you not outside the farm. Even to the valley. Dost hear me? CALEB nods “yes.”  32.
Caleb... (pause. ) Be a good lad and fetch some water for Mother. Stray not from the brook. CALEB looks knowingly at his father and runs away.
AN AXE HEAD splits a LOG. WILLIAM chops wood furiously! He is half dressed with a l sheet wrapped round his waist like a skirt. Chop!

The long dead tendrils of a WILLOW TREE hang around THOMA She wades in a small stream scrubbing her father’s shirt breeches against some rocks, quietly humming a psalm. CALEB is nearby, filling buckets with water, WATCHING HIS SISTER. THOMASIN’S apron and petticoat are tucked into her belt, EXPOSING HER BARE LEGS in the water. CALEB WATCHES HER LEGS...

head_text.subj: AND HER SMALL CHEST RISING UP AND DOWN AT THE TOP OF HER

text: THOMASIN shivers a bit in the cold water as she scrubs. CALEB holds the wooden bucket still in the stream and wat her work. THOMASIN LOOKS UP AND CATCHES HIS GAZE. CALEB gasps silently and looks to his chores.  33.
Why are you dallying? CALEB keeps his eyes on the bucket.
What then? CALEB slows his work again, but keeps looking down.
What? THOMASIN splashes him with water.
Caleb? THOMASIN splashes him again.
Caleb? Big splash. CALEB looks up, hurt and ashamed.
Stop it!
I meant no harm in it. CALEB turns to go.
Caleb, I meant no harm. What’s the matter with thee? Come hither. What’s the matter? CALEB goes to THOMASIN and she takes him in her arms.
What’s the matter with thee? Shhh. CALEB’S eyes well-up with tears. THOMASIN strokes CALEB’S hair as he nestles up to her.
I have seen no apple since we went from England. I would thou hadst found em. I so wish for one.

head_text.subj: THOMASIN MIMES BITING CALEB'S SHOULDER AND MAKES A

text: They laugh a little, though CALEB tries not to. THOMASIN starts humming her psalm again, almost rocking CALEB. They stay for a long time in this innocently incestuous embrace. For once, all is calm. Suddenly, they hear something move in the tall grass and bulrushes: It’s the crackle and snap of many branches. (It sounds ve like the sound THE WITCH made when she ascended into the in the beginning of the film.) CALEB guiltily jumps out of THOMASIN’S arms.
Hear that?
Aye. The “clickety-clackety” sound again.
Who’s there? Long Pause. A child voice speaks, pretending to be old and scratchy:
I be The Witch of the Wood.
Mercy, come out.
I be not Mercy, I be The Witch of the Wood. I have come to steal ye! Hear me stick a-flying through the trees: clickety-clackety-clickety- clakety!
Mercy!  35.
Show thyself! MERCY runs through the bulrushes...
Clickety-clackety-clickety-clakety!
Why is’t when thou dost a wrong, I am a-washing Father's clothes like a slave, and thou art playing idle? MERCY comes out holding a long stick:
Because Mother hates you!
Spoilt child. I’11 tell Mother you have left the farm alone.
Black Phillip saith I can do what I like.
Devil take your Black Phillip.
It’s your fault I cannot leave the yard.
Quiet thee.
I could go to the brook before you let The Witch take Sam.
It was a wolf stole Sam.
A witch. I’ve seen her in her riding cloak about The Wood!
Father showed me the tracks.
It was a witch!!  36.
Aye. It was a witch, Mercy. You speak aright.
Thomasin!
It was I!
Liar.
Twas I what stole him. I’m the witch of the wood.
Liar! Liar!!
I am. THOMASIN smiles the smile of an older sister who know’s h fib is working. And she’s not going to stop.
List not to her Mercy.
I am that very witch. When I sleep my spirit slips away from my body and dances naked with The Devil. That's how I signed his book.
No! THOMASIN grows more serious in her play.
He bade me bring him an unbaptized babe, and I stole Sam, and I gave him to my master. And I’1l make any man or thing else vanish I like.
No.
Aye. And I‘’1l vanish thee too if thou displeaseth me.  37.
Be quiet.
Mercy, she’s but telling fantasies.
Or perchance I’1l boil and bake thee since we are lack of food.
Stop!
Stop Thomasin. MERCY starts crying.
It’s not true! THOMASIN seems very serious now.
It is, thou thing! How I crave to sink my teeth into thy pink flesh.
I’m not afraid of thee!
I’ll make thee afraid before I have done with thee! MERCY starts to run. THOMASIN runs after her and grabs he arm.
Let me go! Let me go! I am not afraid for God hath kept me and will keep me still!
If ever thou tellst thy mother of this, I will witch thee and thy mother! And Jonas too!
Caleb! MERCY cries and runs again. THOMASIN stops her, she pins MERCY down to the ground. THOMASIN SLAPS HER FACE!  38.
Stop thy tears and swear thy silence.
I swear it.
You will not tell Mother nor Father!
I swear!
Thomasin, let her alone! MERCY gets up.
Get away from her Caleb or she’ll witch thee! MERCY runs away. CALEB looks at THOMASIN.
Why tell Mercy those horrible fancies?
Dost thou hate me too?
It was a wolf stole Sam.
I know. She holds back her tears.
Leave me be. Go tell Mother and Father of my wickedness. CALEB walks toward her.
Dost hear me?
Thomaisn, I-  39.
Leave.
I hate thy pity. I need it not.
WILLIAM'S eyes are closed. With open arms, his hands reac above his head and up to Heaven. His words are not rhetorical. They are in earnest.
...and forgive us the sins we have this day committed against thee... EVERYONE is at the table in prayer. Food is very scant.

Free us from the shame and torment which are due unto us for them. We beseech thee, increase our faith in the promises of the gospel, our fear of thy name, and the hatred of all our sins; that we may be assured that thy Holy Spirit dwells in us, that we might be thy children in thy love and mercy. For as we hunger for this food of our bodies, so our souls hunger for the food of eternal life. Finish soon our days of sin, and bring us to everlasting peace through the purifying blood of thy son, our Lord and only Saviour Christ Jesus.
Amen. WILLIAM puts his arms down. CALEB looks at his father. WILLIAM keeps his eyes to his food. THOMASIN looks at Mercy. MERCY looks away with fear.  40.
Thomasin, where hast thou put the silver cup? CALEB looks up from his meal.
Is’t not on the shelf?
Nay.
In the six board then.
T’aint there neither. It has been disappeared for some while. (pause. ) Didst lose it?
I haven't touched it.
Where has it gone then?
I haven't touched it.
I have caught thee trifling with it before.
She sayth she haven’t touched it Katherine.
How thou couldst lose my father’s silver wine cup in this hovel, I cannot know.
I have no-

(overlapping) Peace child, it is gone. Did a wolf vanish that too?  41. THOMASIN’S stomach sinks. CALEB looks at his father. WILLIAM keeps his gaze down on his own dinner. The tension is VERY palpable. Sounds of the crackling fire fill the silence.
She haven’t touched it Katherine. WILLIAM takes another bite of food and wipes his beard. E on his plate. Pause.
What is amiss on this farm? KATHERINE looks down. KATHERINE (CONT’D) It is not natural. JONAS and MERCY look back at THOMASIN with accusatory eye
Caleb? CALEB look at his father nervously... Will he make him confess?
Will you read out the chapter of The Word to-night? CALEB nods “yes,” relieved.
We must find some light in our darkness. To-morrow we will have a fast day but for our sins. Everyone is silent. From outside A GOAT BLEATS.
Thomasin... Another bleat. Louder.  42. KATHERINE (CONT’D) Didst not bed them down before supper? Thomasin?

Another bleat, even wilder. The frightening sound echoes the night. THOMASIN walks alone with a lantern to THE GOAT SHED. Her cloak has been hastily thrown on. The darkness of the farmyard is heavy on her. She can faintly hear CALEB reading from The Bible. As she walks, something moves in the trees. She turns her head to the treetops and hears the “clicket clackety.” Pause. Her breath quickens. She walks closer, cautiously, slowly. A terrible screeching and grunting coming from the GOAT S She walks closer to the open door... she holds up her lam

head_text.subj: INSIDE, BLACK PHILLIP IS VIOLENTLY COPULATING WITH ONE OF

text: NANNY GOATS. THE NANNY GOAT screams as she tries to pull from him. He keeps her in the grasp of his strong legs an muddy hooves. BLACK PHILLIP keeps grunting and thrusting. THOMASIN gasps. She doesn’t look away.
WILLIAM is in bed staring wide eyed at the wall. The bed curtains are open and KATHERINE is kneeling on th floor praying by candlelight.
Love, put out the light. KATHERINE keeps praying.
You must sleep tonight. Kate?  43. KATHERINE finishes her parer and gets into bed. WILLIAM puts his arm around KATHERINE.
Thou dost remember I love thee? She KISSES his large farmer’s HAND.
I do.

List me Kate, I fear thou lookst too much upon this affliction. We must bend our thoughts towards God, not ourselves. (pause. ) He hath never taken a child from us. Never a one, Kate. Who might earn that grace? We have been ungrateful of God’s love. KATHERINE embraces her husband and buries her face in his chest. WILLIAM comforts her the best he can.
He hath cursed this family.
No. He hath taken us into a very low condition to humble us and to show us more of his grace. Still in his embrace, KATHERINE turns away.
Was not Christ was led into the wilderness to be ill met by the devil?
We should ne’er have left the plantation.
Kate —
We should never have left. KATHERINE looks at him. Pause.
That damnéd church!
(overlapping) There is naught hither.
What need we? Silver Chalices? This stings KATHERINE.
How dare you chide me on a cup? Tis not for vanity that I am grieved of it. WILLIAM looks to the wall again. His stomach sinks. He me to confess:
Katherine, I must tell thee-
(overlapping) We might have sold it.
What?
What fool will trade for our corn?
List me Kate, I-
(overlapping) No, listen to me, William:
Kate —
William! Our daughter hath begat the sign of her womanhood...  45. KATHERINE stops, she picks up her voice and calls above. KATHERINE (CONT’D) Thomasin? Caleb? Are y’abed? Mercy? Dead silence.
Jonas? Still silent. KATHERINE closes the bed drapes.
CALEB and THOMASIN are awake, sitting around a burning candle. JONAS and MERCY are tucked in to their bed, awake too. They all listen intently to every word of their parents’ whispers.
(whispering) She’s old enough, she needs must leave to serve another family. THOMASIN is stunned.
Nay, I must have each our hands -
And each our empty stomachs too? THOMASIN’S face sinks. CALEB want to look at her but he doesn’t.
Twas not her fault. I must tell thee Kate-
Aye, it was thine for taking thy family hither.
This is Godly land-  46.
(overlapping) Godly? Our children are being fostered up like savages.
Kate!
How oft I begged and begged thee to take Samuel for baptism.
There was never - I’d not - They’d not baptize outside the congregation -
(overlapping) Our Sam is in hell!
Go to. KATHERINE calms herself.
God save us, Caleb is well. WILLIAM hesitates.
Aye.
He is also near the age of... apprenticeship.
We must keep him still. And Thomasin.
That corn is trash.
We cannot back to that church!
We will starve!  47.

Peace. You'll wake ‘em. Peace. I’11l take the horse to village tomorrow with Thomasin. The Tildens or the Whytings, they can make use of her. They are good folk. Kate. Kate. Stop. We will find food. I know it. CALEB looks over at THOMASIN. She is crying into in her pillow. HOLD ON: CALEB. BLACK.
CALEB, by candlelight, unties THE HORSE’S REINS from a po

(whispering) Caleb! Caleb! He turns and sees THOMASIN walking around the farmyard. S sees him! THOMASIN comes into the barn and quickly hides from the v of the farmhouse. CALEB drops the reins and scrambles away from THE HORSE.
What are you doing? He’s caught. He won’t look at her.
Go to sleep.
What’s this? Tell me now!
THOMASIN sees that BURT THE HORSE has his work-saddle and bridle on.
Running away then?
No.
Lie not to me.
I don’t.
Then what?
Tell me! I’11 wake mother and father. CALEB ignores her.
As you like. THOMASIN starts to head toward the house. CALEB gets scared that she’s not bluffing:
If thou wilt back to sleep, and keep silent of this, I promise thee, you’ll need not leave to serve the Tildens nor any family else.
Caleb -
(overlapping) Tis not pity for thee, so chide me not. I’1ll be back by mid-day. CALEB goes over to the horse.
Let me along with you.
I cannot. THOMASIN gives him a look that she is not to be trifled w  49.

The Wood is still dark. THOMASIN rides BURT. CALEB is on foot, holding the reins leading the way with his flickering lantern. FOWLER trots along beside them. CALEB has the musket. The match-cord is lit.
CALEB finds one of THE TRAPS by THE LARGE OVERTURNED TREE bends down.
Well? CALEB turns to her with a smile! They’ve made a catch!
CALEB and THOMASIN move now with a swifter, more assured pace. A muskrat and other small game hang from the horse’s tack Their spirits are light:
Aye but we did!
Nay.
We did.
No!
We had glass windows in England. We have not been hither so long that you can forget that?
As you like, Thomasin.
You’ve gone mad!  50.
We did.
Dost not remember Fowler laying on the floor i’the sun? You must! And the curious-curled shadows upon his back...?
Nay.

You do! And where the sun would shine, would he warm himself. (to Fowler) Wouldn’t you, thou idler? Remember once he lay upon the table, and Father saw him and he saith “we will have him for meat! Kate, Kate! We will roast this beast”(she laughs). You must remember that!
I remember that day, but no glass. Pause.
Well... THOMASIN is very frustrated that Caleb cannot remember... finds herself surprisingly emotional about this window.
...it was pretty. Suddenly, FOWLER starts tracking something.
What is’t boy?

CALEB and THOMASIN look ahead.  51. Standing about fifty yards before them is same giant HARE from yesterday! BURT IS SPOOKED. He neighs and clomps around, kicking up and tossing his head up oddly. THOMASIN holds tight to th work saddle. CALEB tries to keep his footing.
Burt, calm thee. THOMASIN pats BURT to calm him and CALEB gives her the re THE HARE stays motionless, looking straight at CALEB. CALEB carefully prepares the musket. He takes aim... He shouts:
Fowler, thence! FOWLER RUNS toward THE HARE, barking loudly! BURT neighs again, going rampant, nearly knocking THOMASI off.
Burt!

head_text.subj: THE HARE RUNS DEEP INTO THE WOOD

text: Fowler Nay! Fowler!

head_text.subj: HE SHOUTS BACK TO THOMASIN AS HE RUNS

text: Stand here with Burt!
Caleb, he’s gone mad!
(overlapping) I'll straight back! BUT IT IS TOO LATE...  52.

head_text.subj: THE HORSE REARS AND BUCKS AGAIN, KNOCKING THOMASIN TO THE
GROUND AND GALLOPS OFF IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION OF FOWLE
THOMASIN IS LEFT UNCONSCIOUS ON THE FOREST FLOOR.

text: CALEB travels deeper into The Wood, running. THE TREES have become more indiscernible from one another Tall seemingly identical trunks stand looming in every direction. He stops, panting. He turns around.
Thomasin? Thomasin! He hears nothing. He tries to whistle for Fowler like his father does. It c out airy and quiet.
Folwer! He attempts to whistle again. It doesn't work.
JONAS AND MERCY are tethered to a long rope tied to the f so they cannot wander from the farm. THE GOAT-BELLS from nanny goats have also been tied to them.

Caleb! Caleb! THE BELLS CLANK as they walk. KATHERINE and WILLIAM are in the distant fields near THE searching, calling their children's names. A light rain starts to fall. It plinks on the GOAT-BELLS.
(in the distance) Caleb, lad! Thomasin!
THOMASIN wakes.  53.
Caleb? SHE stand, uneasy. She looks around. SHE knows where she is. She is near OVERTURNED TREE where Caleb set the first trap. How did she get there? She turns back.
Caleb! Burt?! Nothing.
Caleb!! She runs on toward home!
CALEB holds his musket ready. THE TREES and underbrush ha become even more dense and tangled. He prays aloud as he walks:

O God my Lord, I now begin, O help me and I'll leave my sin. For I repentant now will be, From evil I will turn to thee. None ever shall destroy my faith, Nor do I mind what Satan saith. O God my Lord, I now begin, O help me and I'll leave my sin - He hears the yelp of the dog. It echoes in the wood. He runs fast after the noise. He cannot see through the m He keeps running. Running. He trips and falls.

head_text.subj: IN FRONT OF HIM ARE THE BLOODY REMAINS OF FOWLER, STILL H

text: THOMASIN clumsily weaves through crackling branches. Daylight is waning. She breaths heavily, trying to run, but she is exhausted. All of a sudden, she hears something faint... voices! They are almost inaudible:
Caleb! Thomasin!
Caleb! She picks up her pace!

CALEB trudges through a strange winding path of dense, twisting, vines and thorns. He tries to run, but the rain, fog, and spiky terrain slo him down. His stockings get caught on some thorns. He recoils in pain and drops THE MUSKET. He tries to disentangle himself, further cutting his fing and legs. He tries to pick up the musket but it is caught in THE THORNS. He pulls and pulls and it only makes things worse His hands bleed more. He is crying. IN THE DISTANCE IS A SWEET MELODY. A WOMAN HUMMING. He turns his head to find where the music is coming from. A few yards in front of him is THE HARE! THE HARE JUMPS AWAY. CALEB FOLLOWS, LEAVING THE MUSKET IN THE RAIN.
THOMASIN comes to the edge of the tree line and sees her  55. father in the last light of dusk.
Father! Father! He hears her and runs toward her!
Thomasin! They meet, WILLIAM picks her up in his arms.
Thomasin! My girl. He hugs her tight in the rain. He rubs his cheek on hers. WILLIAM looks into her glassy eyes:

Where is thy brother? EXT. WITCH’S HOVEL - DUSK CALEB emerges from the barbed path to see a faint warm li The humming is more distinct. Through the mist and rain THE WITCH’S HOVEL becomes visib The pointed structure sits up high on four knotted tree trunks. Matted branches overhang its sagging moss-grown thatch-roof, upon which there is no chimney, just a hole puffing smoke. The whole thing looks held together by ill omened weeds, plants, and sinister roots that grow all ov and through the muddy walls like a plague. A rotting foot-ladder leads up to the slightly open front door. Firelight glows from within. CALEB continues to walk toward the humming. THE HARE is nowhere to be seen. He stumbles through a large FIRE PIT with BONES strewn ab the ground. Rain plinks on a huge IRON CAULDRON in the ce of the pit. Just then, THE DOOR opens wider... CALEB stops short. Out steps a BEAUTIFUL WOMAN (20s) IN A RED CLOAK. She smo a small CLAY PIPE.  56. CALEB steps back. He is soaking wet. He tries his best to stop crying, to no avail. THE WOMAN comes forward and her very dirty, but dainty, b foot takes one step down the foot ladder. She leans forward. She reaches her arms out sympathetical toward CALEB. Her face is greasy, but stunning. Her filthy bodice is cu quite low. There are a few small moles on her ample breas CALEB sees this all. He stays still. The rain falls. THE WOMAN beckons him. CALEB walks toward her, he is drawn to her. He can’t help it. She crouches on the foot ladder. CALEB is now face to face with her. She smiles at CALEB. Some of her teeth are crooked and browned near the gums, is startling, but she is beautiful all the same. She strokes CALEB’S head and embraces him. Tears still fall from CALEB’S eyes. He trembles. He looks at THE WOMAN’S face, he looks into her hypnotic AMBER EYES. She smiles so sweetly. She draws CALEB NEAR.

head_text.subj: SHE KISSES CALEB SENSUALLY ON THE MOUTH
SUDDENLY, HER HAND, NOW OLD AND UGLY, CREEPS AROUND AND G
THE BACK OF HIS HEAD LIKE A CLAW. SHE PUSHES HIS MOUTH

text: CLOSE ON: THOMASIN standing against the wall, shaking. Guilty. Soaking wet.
What’s the matter with thee Thomasin? What’s the matter with thee? THOMASIN cannot move.
I'll leave at first light and I'1l1 return not till I find him.
Twould be better to go to the village and raise up help. I cannot bear -
(overlapping) Tis a days ride and I have not a horse. There is not time to be lost.
Likely you should have left this morn then.
You have no gun, William, nay, not even a dog. Be not a fool. 57. THOMASIN watches WILLIAM get up and put on his wet cloak hat.
I am a fool to go. There is none will help our family. WILLIAM rummages through the house.

Where’s the lanthorn? He rummages some more. He can’t find it. In frustration, WILLIAM shouts: he throws something acros the room with a bang. THOMASIN covers her eyes. JONAS AND MERCY cower in the corner.  58.
Be it so. The moon is bright. Rain bothers me not. I’1l be back in a two day -- If any a man will return with me.
Don’t go Father!
(overlapping) Please you Father, don’t go!
Enough. (to Thomasin, calmly.) Tell us why you went into The Wood.
I promised. THOMASIN exchanges a quick glance with her father.
I care not.
Let me find favor in your eyes.
Child, tell me and thou wilt.
Speak! WILLIAM steps out from the shadows of the room.
I took thy father’s cup. (pause. ) I sold it. Forgive me Kate. Forgive me Thomasin.
What is this?
Kate, I must make a confession... (pause. ) I, yestermorn, I took Caleb to The Wood.
RAIN pelts down upon the tiny house. KATHERINE bursts out of the door into the rain. WILLIAM runs after her.
Twas for food - and the pelts for money. Good money.
(overlapping) I knew you were false! I knew it!
I did want it a surprise, twas why I kept silent. I will trap that wolf. Stop! Stop Kate! WILLIAM grabs hold of her arm.
You stood by whilst our son lied to me!
‘Twas for thy sake. I love thee Kate.
You took him to the Wood!
I will find him.
You have broken God’s covenant. You are a liar. And you have lost another child. 59.
(overlapping) I will go now!
You cannot escape the wood!
I will find him!
And kill thyself too? Will Jonas be the man of the house? Will you damn all your family to death?!
Kate-
(overlapping) Let go of me. THEY struggle.
I will find my son! KATHERINE slaps WILLIAM very hard in the face. WILLIAM lifts his hand to strike his wife.

Father! THE CHILDREN are gathered by the open door. They watch th parents fight in the rain. WILLIAM sees his children. He puts his hand down, he picks up KATHERINE in his arms, walks toward the house.

THOMASIN tends to her father’s bloody nose by THE HEARTH. WILLIAM shivers in his wet clothes. He looks at his daugh ashamed. KATHERINE sits on the other side of the fire holding JONA AND MERCY in her arms. She rocks them back in forth.  61.
Picking apples. Silence. THOMASIN looks at KATHERINE.
Mother, have the goats been bedded down?
Nay.
I will to it.
Let it wait till the morrow. They dare not scape with this rain.
Nay, I will to it. Please you, Mother.

Come hither child. THOMASIN walks to her mother... KATHERINE embraces THOMASIN along with her other remainin children. Pause. KATHERINE looks at THOMASIN’S yearning face. She kisses h warmly. KATHERINE (CONT’D) Hurry back.

THOMASIN proudly pets THE NANNY GOATS and sooths them. BL PHILLIP stands by, his horns casting enormous shadows fro THOMASIN’S LANTERN LIGHT. THOMASIN brings one of THE WHITE NANNIES down to the grou No sound but the pitter-patter of the rain outside. Long Pause.  62. SUDDENLY, THOMASIN hears the sound of FOOTSTEPS outside i the grass... More footsteps. Stumbling around. SHE HEARS THE SOUND of a wooden creak. THOMASIN is still. She hears the wood creak again more forcefully. THOMASIN flees from the GOAT SHED to see what it is...
IT’S CALEB! WET. NAKED. PALE AS DEATH. He grasps a FENCE-POST trying to stay standing in the pou rain. THOMASIN runs to him. SHE embraces him. He is shivering.
Caleb. Caleb! CALEB collapses in THOMASIN’S arms. THOMASIN shrieks:
Father! Mother! THOMASIN brings her lamp to CALEB’S face:

head_text.subj: HIS EYES ROLL TO THE BACK OF HIS HEAD. HE OPENS HIS MOUTH

text: Shutters are closed. Several tapers are lit. CALEB is in his straw bed breathing stertorously. His eye are closed. There are several small scabs around his mout His lips move slightly, occasionally muttering something inaudible. THOMASIN wipes the perspiration from his brow. KATHERINE takes a broad strip of linen and sprinkles it w herbs. Then she holds a taper into the flame of a wood-  63. candle. The flame billows a thick smoke as KATHERINE drip the hot tallow over the herbs. She places this poulticed cloth over CALEB’S bare stomach and ties it taught with THOMASIN’S help. JONAS & MERCY sit by his pillow and touch him gently with their tiny fingers. THE TWINS LOOK AT THOMASIN WITH SUSPICION. THOMASIN tries ignore this. KATHERINE gives THOMASIN a small bowl to hold by CALEB’S head. KATHERINE takes her knife and makes a small cut ina protruding vein in CALEB’S temple. BLOOD drips into the b KATHERINE begins to pray. THOMASIN looks at her father. WILLIAM stands reticently from a couple paces back, leani his hand on one of the beams of the garret.
WILLIAM IN THE POURING RAIN, chops wood. CHOP.

THOMASIN is in the shed with A PAIL and milking stool, readying one of THE NANNY GOATS for milking. SHE looks over at THE TWINS: They sit in the fodder with BLACK PHILLIP.
